CHAPTER XIV.
Clara’s Confession
ON the Monday evening before the picnic Edna came down from her room with a troubled face.

“Clara,” she said to that small personage, who was shelling peas by the spotless table and singing, “Nelly of the Hazel Dell” with a vigor and expression that did credit to Sophia’s teaching, “did you see anything of my amethyst brooch? I thought I stuck it in my pincushion when I came home from church yesterday evening, but I can’t find it anywhere.”

“I—I saw it this afternoon when you were away at the Aid Society,” said Clara, a little slowly. “I was passing your door when I saw it on the cushion, so I went in to look at it.”

“Did you touch it?” said Edna sternly.

“Y-e-e-s,” admitted Clara, “I took it up and I pinned it on my breast just to see how it would look.”

“You had no business to do anything of the sort. It’s very wrong in a little girl to meddle. You shouldn’t have gone into my room in the first place and you shouldn’t have touched a brooch that didn’t belong to you in the second. Where did you put it?”

“Oh, I put it back on the bureau. I hadn’t it on a minute. Truly, I didn’t mean to meddle, Edna. I didn’t think about its being wrong to go in and try on the brooch; but I see now that it was and I’ll never do it again. That’s one good thing about me. I never do the same naughty thing twice.”

“You didn’t put it back,” said Edna. “That brooch isn’t anywhere on the bureau. You’ve taken it out or something, Clara.”

“I did put it back,” said Clara quickly—pertly, Edna thought. “I don’t just remember whether I stuck it on the pincushion or laid it in the china tray. But I’m perfectly certain I put it back.”

“I’ll go and have another look,” said Edna, determining to be just. “If you put that brooch back it’s there still. If it isn’t I’ll know you didn’t, that’s all!”

Edna went to her room and made a thorough search, not only over the bureau but in every other place she thought the brooch might possibly be. It was not to be found and she returned to the kitchen.

“Clara, the brooch is gone. By your own admission you were the last person to handle it. Now, what have you done with it? Tell me the truth at once. Did you take it out and lose it?”

“No, I didn’t,” said Clara solemnly, meeting Edna’s angry gaze squarely. “I never took the brooch out of your room and that is the truth, if I was to be led to the block for it—although I’m not very certain what a block is. So there, Edna.”

Clara’s “so there” was only intended to emphasize her assertion, but Edna took it as a display of defiance.

“I believe you are telling me a falsehood, Clara,” she said sharply. “I know you are. There now, don’t say anything more unless you are prepared to tell the whole truth. Go to your room and stay there until you are ready to confess.”

“Will I take the peas with me?” said Clara meekly.

“No, I’ll finish shelling them myself. Do as I bid you.”

When Clara had gone Edna went about her evening tasks in a very disturbed state of mind. She was worried about her valuable brooch. What if Clara had lost it? And how wicked of the child to deny having taken it, when anybody could see she must have! With such an innocent face, too!

“I don’t know what I wouldn’t sooner have had happen,” thought Edna, as she nervously shelled the peas. “Of course, I don’t suppose she meant to steal it or anything like that. She’s just taken it to play with or help along that imagination of hers. She must have taken it, that’s clear, for there hasn’t been a soul in that room since she was in it, by her own story, until I went up tonight. And the brooch is gone, there’s nothing surer. I suppose she has lost it and is afraid to own up for fear she’ll be punished. It’s a dreadful thing to think she tells falsehoods. It’s a far worse thing than her fit of temper. It’s a fearful responsibility to have a child in your house you can’t trust. Slyness and untruthfulness—that’s what she has displayed. I declare I feel worse about that than about the brooch. If she’d only have told the truth about it I wouldn’t mind so much.”

Edna went to her room at intervals all through the evening and searched for the brooch, without finding it. A bedtime visit to the east gable produced no result. Clara persisted in denying that she knew anything about the brooch but Edna was only the more firmly convinced that she did.

She told Donald the story the next morning. Donald was confounded and puzzled; he could not so quickly lose faith in Clara but he had to admit that circumstances were against her.

“You’re sure it hasn’t fell down behind the bureau?” was the only suggestion he could offer.

“I’ve moved the bureau and I’ve taken out the drawers and I’ve looked in every crack and cranny” was Edna’s positive answer. “The brooch is gone and that child has taken it and lied about it. That’s the plain, ugly truth, Donald Forsythe, and we might as well look it in the face.”

“Well now, what are you going to do about it?” Donald asked forlornly, feeling secretly thankful that Edna and not he had to deal with the situation. He felt no desire to put his oar in this time.

“She’ll stay in her room until she confesses,” said Edna grimly, remembering the success of this method in the former case. “Then we’ll see. Perhaps we’ll be able to find the brooch if she’ll only tell where she took it; but in any case she’ll have to be severely punished, Donald.”

“Well now, you’ll have to punish her,” said Donald, reaching for his hat. “I’ve nothing to do with it, remember. You warned me off yourself.”

Edna felt deserted by everyone. She could not even go to Mrs. Harper for advice. She went up to the east gable with a very serious face and left it with a face more serious still. Clara steadfastly refused to confess. She persisted in asserting that she had not taken the brooch. The child had evidently been crying and Edna felt a pang of pity which she sternly repressed. By night she was, as she expressed it, “beat out.”

“You’ll stay in this room until you confess, Clara. You can make up your mind to that,” she said firmly.

“But the picnic is tomorrow, Edna,” cried Clara. “You won’t keep me from going to that, will you? You’ll just let me out for the afternoon, won’t you? Then I’ll stay here as long as you like afterwards cheerfully. But I must go to the picnic.”

“You’ll not go to picnics nor anywhere else until you’ve confessed, Clara.”

“Oh, Edna,” gasped Clara.

But Edna had gone out and shut the door.

Wednesday morning dawned as bright and fair as if expressly made to order for the picnic. Birds sang around Green Gables; the Madonna lilies in the garden sent out whiffs of perfume that entered in on viewless winds at every door and window, and wandered through halls and rooms like spirits of benediction. The birches in the hollow waved joyful hands as if watching for Clara’s usual morning greeting from the east gable. But Clara was not at her window. When Edna took her breakfast up to her she found the child sitting primly on her bed, pale and resolute, with tight-shut lips and gleaming eyes.

“Edna, I’m ready to confess.”

“Ah!” Edna laid down her tray. Once again her method had succeeded; but her success was very bitter to her. “Let me hear what you have to say then, Clara.”

“I took the amethyst brooch,” said Clara, as if repeating a lesson she had learned. “I took it just as you said. I didn’t mean to take it when I went in. But it did look so beautiful, Edna, when I pinned it on my breast that I was overcome by an irresistible temptation. I imagined how perfectly thrilling it would be to take it to Idlewild and play I was the Lady Veronica Lancaster. It would be so much easier to imagine I was the Lady Veronica if I had a real amethyst brooch on. Sophia and I make necklaces of roseberries but what are roseberries compared to amethysts? So I took the brooch. I thought I could put it back before you came home. I went all the way around by the road to lengthen out the time. When I was going over the bridge across the Lake of Shining Waters I took the brooch off to have another look at it. Oh, how it did shine in the sunlight! And then, when I was leaning over the bridge, it just slipped through my fingers—so—and went down—down—down, all purply-sparkling, and sank forevermore beneath the Lake of Shining Waters. And that’s the best I can do at confessing, Edna.”

Edna felt hot anger surge up into her heart again. This child had taken and lost her treasured amethyst brooch and now sat there calmly reciting the details thereof without the least apparent compunction or repentance.

“Clara, this is terrible,” she said, trying to speak calmly. “You are the very wickedest girl I ever heard of.”

“Yes, I suppose I am,” agreed Clara tranquilly. “And I know I’ll have to be punished. It’ll be your duty to punish me, Edna. Won’t you please get it over right off because I’d like to go to the picnic with nothing on my mind.”

“Picnic, indeed! You’ll go to no picnic today, Clara Fisher. That shall be your punishment. And it isn’t half severe enough either for what you’ve done!”

“Not go to the picnic!” Clara sprang to her feet and clutched Edna’s hand. “But you promised me I might! Oh, Edna, I must go to the picnic. That was why I confessed. Punish me any way you like but that. Oh, Edna, please, please, let me go to the picnic. Think of the ice cream! For anything you know I may never have a chance to taste ice cream again.”

Edna disengaged Clara’s clinging hands stonily.

“You needn’t plead, Clara. You are not going to the picnic and that’s final. No, not a word.”

Clara realized that Edna was not to be moved. She clasped her hands together, gave a piercing shriek, and then flung herself face downward on the bed, crying and writhing in an utter abandonment of disappointment and despair.

“For the land’s sake!” gasped Edna, hastening from the room. “I believe the child is crazy. No child in her senses would behave as she does. If she isn’t she’s utterly bad. Oh dear, I’m afraid Beatrice was right from the first. But I’ve put my hand to the plow and I won’t look back.”

That was a dismal morning. Edna worked fiercely and scrubbed the porch floor and the dairy shelves when she could find nothing else to do. Neither the shelves nor the porch needed it—but Edna did. Then she went out and raked the yard.

When dinner was ready she went to the stairs and called Clara. A tear-stained face appeared, looking tragically over the banisters.

“Come down to your dinner, Clara.”

“I don’t want any dinner, Edna,” said Clara, sobbingly. “I couldn’t eat anything. My heart is broken. You’ll feel remorse of conscience someday, I expect, for breaking it, Edna, but I forgive you. Remember when the time comes that I forgive you. But please don’t ask me to eat anything, especially boiled pork and greens. Boiled pork and greens are so unromantic when one is in affliction.”

Exasperated, Edna returned to the kitchen and poured out her tale of woe to Donald, who, between his sense of justice and his unlawful sympathy with Clara, was a miserable man.

“Well now, she shouldn’t have taken the brooch, Edna, or told stories about it,” he admitted, mournfully surveying his plateful of unromantic pork and greens as if he, like Clara, thought it a food unsuited to crises of feeling, “but she’s such a little thing—such an interesting little thing. Don’t you think it’s pretty rough not to let her go to the picnic when she’s so set on it?”

“Donald Forsythe, I’m amazed at you. I think I’ve let her off entirely too easy. And she doesn’t appear to realize how wicked she’s been at all—that’s what worries me most. If she’d really felt sorry it wouldn’t be so bad. And you don’t seem to realize it, neither; you’re making excuses for her all the time to yourself—I can see that.”

“Well now, she’s such a little thing,” feebly reiterated Donald. “And there should be allowances made, Edna. You know she’s never had any bringing up.”

“Well, she’s having it now” retorted Edna.

The retort silenced Donald if it did not convince him. That dinner was a very dismal meal. The only cheerful thing about it was Max Fontaine, the hired boy, and Edna resented his cheerfulness as a personal insult.

When her dishes were washed and her bread sponge set and her hens fed Edna remembered that she had noticed a small rent in her best black lace shawl when she had taken it off on Monday afternoon on returning from the Ladies’ Aid.

She would go and mend it. The shawl was in a box in her trunk. As Edna lifted it out, the sunlight, falling through the vines that clustered thickly about the window, struck upon something caught in the shawl—something that glittered and sparkled in facets of violet light. Edna snatched at it with a gasp. It was the amethyst brooch, hanging to a thread of the lace by its catch!

“Dear life and heart,” said Edna blankly, “what does this mean? Here’s my brooch safe and sound that I thought was at the bottom of Barry’s pond. Whatever did that girl mean by saying she took it and lost it? I declare I believe Green Gables is bewitched. I remember now that when I took off my shawl Monday afternoon I laid it on the bureau for a minute. I suppose the brooch got caught in it somehow. Well!”

Edna betook herself to the east gable, brooch in hand. Clara had cried herself out and was sitting dejectedly by the window.

“Clara Fisher,” said Edna solemnly, “I’ve just found my brooch hanging to my black lace shawl. Now I want to know what that rigmarole you told me this morning meant.”

“Why, you said you’d keep me here until I confessed,” returned Clara wearily, “and so I decided to confess because I was bound to get to the picnic. I thought out a confession last night after I went to bed and made it as interesting as I could. And I said it over and over so that I wouldn’t forget it. But you wouldn’t let me go to the picnic after all, so all my trouble was wasted.”

Edna had to laugh in spite of herself. But her conscience pricked her.

“Clara, you do beat all! But I was wrong—I see that now. I shouldn’t have doubted your word when I’d never known you to tell a story. Of course, it wasn’t right for you to confess to a thing you hadn’t done—it was very wrong to do so. But I drove you to it. So if you’ll forgive me, Clara, I’ll forgive you and we’ll start square again. And now get yourself ready for the picnic.”

Clara flew up like a rocket.

“Oh, Edna, isn’t it too late?”

“No, it’s only two o’clock. They won’t be more than well gathered yet and it’ll be an hour before they have tea. Wash your face and comb your hair and put on your gingham. I’ll fill a basket for you. There’s plenty of stuff baked in the house. And I’ll get Max to hitch up the sorrel and drive you down to the picnic ground.”

“Oh, Edna,” exclaimed Clara, flying to the washstand. “Five minutes ago I was so miserable I was wishing I’d never been born and now I wouldn’t change places with an angel!”

That night a thoroughly happy, completely tired-out Clara returned to Green Gables in a state of beatification impossible to describe.

“Oh, Edna, I’ve had a perfectly scrumptious time. Scrumptious is a new word I learned today. I heard Nora Carter use it. Isn’t it very expressive? Everything was lovely. We had a splendid tea and then Mr. Marvin Chapman took us all for a row on the Lake of Shining Waters—six of us at a time. And Martha Chapman nearly fell overboard. She was leaning out to pick water lilies and if Mr. Chapman hadn’t caught her by her sash just in the nick of time she’d fallen in and prob’ly been drowned. I wish it had been me. It would have been such a romantic experience to have been nearly drowned. It would be such a thrilling tale to tell. And we had the ice cream. Words fail me to describe that ice cream. Edna, I assure you it was sublime.”

That evening Edna told the whole story to Donald over her stocking basket.

“I’m willing to own up that I made a mistake,” she concluded candidly, “but I’ve learned a lesson. I have to laugh when I think of Clara’s ‘confession,’ although I suppose I shouldn’t for it really was a falsehood. But it doesn’t seem as bad as the other would have been, somehow, and anyhow I’m responsible for it. That child is hard to understand in some respects. But I believe she’ll turn out all right yet. And there’s one thing certain, no house will ever be dull that she’s in.”

CHAPTER XV.
A Tempest in the School Teapot
WHAT a splendid day!” said Clara, drawing a long breath. “Isn’t it good just to be alive on a day like this? I pity the people who aren’t born yet for missing it. They may have good days, of course, but they can never have this one. And it’s splendider still to have such a lovely way to go to school by, isn’t it?”

“It’s a lot nicer than going round by the road; that is so dusty and hot,” said Sophia practically, peeping into her dinner basket and mentally calculating if the three juicy, toothsome, raspberry tarts reposing there were divided among ten girls how many bites each girl would have.

The little girls of Avonlea school always pooled their lunches, and to eat three raspberry tarts all alone or even to share them only with one’s best chum would have forever and ever branded as “awful mean” the girl who did it. And yet, when the tarts were divided among ten girls you just got enough to tantalize you.

The way Clara and Sophia went to school was a pretty one. Clara thought those walks to and from school with Sophia couldn’t be improved upon even by imagination. Going around by the main road would have been so unromantic; but to go by Lover’s Lane and Willowmere and Violet Vale and the Birch Path was romantic, if ever anything was.

Lover’s Lane opened out below the orchard at Green Gables and stretched far up into the woods to the end of the Cuthbert farm. It was the way by which the cows were taken to the back pasture and the wood hauled home in winter. Clara had named it Lover’s Lane before she had been a month at Green Gables.

“Not that lovers ever really walk there,” she explained to Edna, “but Sophia and I are reading a perfectly magnificent book and there’s a Lover’s Lane in it. So we want to have one, too. And it’s a very pretty name, don’t you think? So romantic! We can’t imagine the lovers into it, you know. I like that lane because you can think out loud there without people calling you crazy.”

Clara, starting out alone in the morning, went down Lover’s Lane as far as the brook. Here Sophia met her, and the two little girls went on up the lane under the leafy arch of maples—“maples are such sociable trees,” said Clara; “they’re always rustling and whispering to you”—until they came to a rustic bridge. Then they left the lane and walked through Mr. Greene’s back field and past Willowmere. Beyond Willowmere came Violet Vale—a little green dimple in the shadow of Mr. Andrew Bell’s big woods. “Of course there are no violets there now,” Clara told Edna, “but Sophia says there are millions of them in spring. Oh, Edna, can’t you just imagine you see them? It actually takes away my breath. I named it Violet Vale. Sophia says she never saw the beat of me for hitting on fancy names for places. It’s nice to be clever at something, isn’t it? But Sophia named the Birch Path. She wanted to, so I let her; but I’m sure I could have found something more poetical than plain Birch Path. Anybody can think of a name like that. But the Birch Path is one of the prettiest places in the world, Edna.”

It was. Other people besides Clara thought so when they stumbled on it. It was a little narrow, twisting path, winding down over a long hill straight through Mr. Carter’s woods, where the light came down sifted through so many emerald screens that it was as flawless as the heart of a diamond. It was fringed in all its length with slim young birches, white stemmed and lissom boughed; ferns and starflowers and wild lilies-of-the-valley and scarlet tufts of pigeonberries grew thickly along it; and always there was a delightful spiciness in the air and music of bird calls and the murmur and laugh of wood winds in the trees overhead. Now and then you might see a rabbit skipping across the road if you were quiet—which, with Clara and Sophia, happened about once in a blue moon. Down in the valley the path came out to the main road and then it was just up the spruce hill to the school.

The Avonlea school was a whitewashed building, low in the eaves and wide in the windows, furnished inside with comfortable substantial old-fashioned desks that opened and shut, and were carved all over their lids with the initials and hieroglyphics of three generations of school children. The schoolhouse was set back from the road and behind it was a dusky fir wood and a brook where all the children put their bottles of milk in the morning to keep cool and sweet until dinner hour.

Edna had seen Clara start off to school on the first day of September with many secret misgivings. Clara was such an odd girl. How would she get on with the other children? And how on earth would she ever manage to hold her tongue during school hours?

Things went better than Edna feared, however. Clara came home that evening in high spirits.

“I think I’m going to like school here,” she announced. “I don’t think much of the master, though. He’s all the time curling his mustache and making eyes at Lena Chapman. Lena is grown up, you know. She’s sixteen and she’s studying for the entrance examination into Queen’s Academy at Charlottetown next year. Emma Conner says the master is dead gone on her. She’s got a beautiful complexion and curly brown hair and she does it up so elegantly. She sits in the long seat at the back and he sits there, too, most of the time—to explain her lessons, he says. But Coral Hayes says she saw him writing something on her slate and when Lena read it she blushed as red as a beet and giggled; and Coral Hayes says she doesn’t believe it had anything to do with the lesson.”

“Clara Fisher, don’t let me hear you talking about your teacher in that way again,” said Edna sharply. “You don’t go to school to criticize the master. I guess he can teach you something, and it’s your business to learn. And I want you to understand right off that you are not to come home telling tales about him. That is something I won’t encourage. I hope you were a good girl.”

“Indeed I was,” said Clara comfortably. “It wasn’t so hard as you might imagine, either. I sit with Sophia. Our seat is right by the window and we can look down to the Lake of Shining Waters. There are a lot of nice girls in school and we had scrumptious fun playing at dinnertime. It’s so nice to have a lot of little girls to play with. But of course I like Sophia best and always will. I adore Sophia. I’m dreadfully far behind the others. They’re all in the fifth book and I’m only in the fourth. I feel that it’s kind of a disgrace. But there’s not one of them has such an imagination as I have and I soon found that out. We had reading and geography and Canadian history and dictation today. Mr. Edwards said my spelling was disgraceful and he held up my slate so that everybody could see it, all marked over. I felt so mortified, Edna; he might have been politer to a stranger, I think. Coral Hayes gave me an apple and Clara Russell lent me a lovely pink card with ‘May I see you home?’ on it. I’m to give it back to her tomorrow. And Emma Conner let me wear her bead ring all the afternoon. Can I have some of those pearl beads off the old pincushion in the garret to make myself a ring? And oh, Edna, Martha Chapman told me that Dolly Wilson told her that she heard Lena Chapman tell Harper Hayes that I had a very pretty nose. Edna, that is the first compliment I have ever had in my life and you can’t imagine what a strange feeling it gave me. Edna, have I really a pretty nose? I know you’ll tell me the truth.”

“Your nose is well enough,” said Edna shortly. Secretly she thought Clara’s nose was a remarkable pretty one; but she had no intention of telling her so.

That was three weeks ago and all had gone smoothly so far. And now, this crisp September morning, Clara and Sophia were tripping blithely down the Birch Path, two of the happiest little girls in Avonlea.

“I guess Rowan Blake will be in school today,” said Sophia. “He’s been visiting his cousins over in New Brunswick all summer and he only came home Saturday night. He’s aw’fly handsome, Clara. And he teases the girls something terrible. He just torments our lives out.”

Sophia’s voice indicated that she rather liked having her life tormented out than not.

“Rowan Blake?” said Clara. “Isn’t his name that’s written up on the porch wall with Olive Carter’s and a big ‘Take Notice’ over them?”

“Yes,” said Sophia, tossing her head, “but I’m sure he doesn’t like Olive Carter so very much. I’ve heard him say he studied the multiplication table by her freckles.”

“Oh, don’t speak about freckles to me,” implored Clara. “It isn’t delicate when I’ve got so many. But I do think that writing take-notices up on the wall about the boys and girls is the silliest ever. I should just like to see anybody dare to write my name up with a boy’s. Not, of course,” she hastened to add, “that anybody would.”

Clara sighed. She didn’t want her name written up. But it was a little humiliating to know that there was no danger of it.

“Nonsense,” said Sophia, whose black eyes and glossy tresses had played such havoc with the hearts of Avonlea schoolboys that her name figured on the porch walls in half a dozen take-notices. “It’s only meant as a joke. And don’t you be too sure your name won’t ever be written up. Jack Russell is dead gone on you. He told his mother—his mother, mind you—that you were the smartest girl in school. That’s better than being good looking.”

“No, it isn’t,” said Clara, feminine to the core. “I’d rather be pretty than clever. And I hate Jack Russell, I can’t bear a boy with goggle eyes. If anyone wrote my name up with his I’d never get over it, Sophia Greene. But it is nice to keep head of your class.”

“You’ll have Rowan in your class after this,” said Sophia, “and he’s used to being head of his class, I can tell you. He’s only in the fourth book although he’s nearly fourteen. Four years ago his father was sick and had to go out to Alberta for his health and Rowan went with him. They were there three years and Gil didn’t go to school hardly any until they came back. You won’t find it so easy to keep head after this, Clara.”

“I’m glad,” said Clara quickly. “I couldn’t really feel proud of keeping head of little boys and girls of just nine or ten. I got up yesterday spelling ‘ebullition.’ Hannah Ford was head and, mind you, she peeped in her book. Mr. Edwards didn’t see her—he was looking at Lena Chapman—but I did. I just swept her a look of freezing scorn and she got as red as a beet and spelled it wrong after all.”

“Those Pye girls are cheats all round,” said Sophia indignantly, as they climbed the fence of the main road. “Heather Ford actually went and put her milk bottle in my place in the brook yesterday. Did you ever? I don’t speak to her now.”

When Mr. Edwards was in the back of the room hearing Lena Chapman’s Latin, Sophia whispered to Clara, “That’s Rowan Blake sitting right across the aisle from you, Clara. Just look at him and see if you don’t think he’s handsome.”

Clara looked accordingly. She had a good chance to do so, for the said Rowan Blake was absorbed in stealthily pinning the long yellow braid of Coral Hayes, who sat in front of him, to the back of her seat. He was a tall boy, with curly brown hair, roguish hazel eyes, and a mouth twisted into a teasing smile. Presently Coral Hayes started up to take a sum to the master; she fell back into her seat with a little shriek, believing that her hair was pulled out by the roots. Everybody looked at her and Mr. Edwards glared so sternly that Coral began to cry. Rowan had whisked the pin out of sight and was studying his history with the soberest face in the world; but when the commotion subsided he looked at Clara and winked with inexpressible drollery.

“I think your Rowan Blake is handsome,” confided Clara to Sophia, “but I think he’s very bold. It isn’t good manners to wink at a strange girl.”

But it was not until the afternoon that things really began to happen.

Mr. Edwards was back in the corner explaining a problem in algebra to Lena Chapman and the rest of the scholars were doing pretty much as they pleased eating green apples, whispering, drawing pictures on their slates, and driving crickets harnessed to strings, up and down aisle. Rowan Blake was trying to make Clara Fisher look at him and failing utterly, because Clara was at that moment totally oblivious not only to the very existence of Rowan Blake, but of every other scholar in Avonlea school itself. With her chin propped on her hands and her eyes fixed on the blue glimpse of the Lake of Shining Waters that the west window afforded, she was far away in a gorgeous dreamland hearing and seeing nothing save her own wonderful visions.

Rowan Blake wasn’t used to putting himself out to make a girl look at him and meeting with failure. She should look at him, that red-haired Shirley girl with the little pointed chin and the big eyes that weren’t like the eyes of any other girl in Avonlea school.

Rowan reached across the aisle, picked up the end of Clara’s long red braid, held it out at arm’s length and said in a piercing whisper:

“Carrots! Carrots!”

Then Clara looked at him with a vengeance!

She did more than look. She sprang to her feet, her bright fancies fallen into cureless ruin. She flashed one indignant glance at Rowan from eyes whose angry sparkle was swiftly quenched in equally angry tears.

“You mean, hateful boy!” she exclaimed passionately. “How dare you!”

And then—thwack! Clara had brought her slate down on Rowan’s head and cracked it—slate not head—clear across.

Avonlea school always enjoyed a scene. This was an especially enjoyable one. Everybody said “Oh” in horrified delight. Sophia gasped. Coral Hayes, who was inclined to be hysterical, began to cry. Jake Russell let his team of crickets escape him altogether while he stared open-mouthed at the tableau.

Mr. Edwards stalked down the aisle and laid his hand heavily on Clara’s shoulder.

“Clara Fisher, what does this mean?” he said angrily. Clara returned no answer. It was asking too much of flesh and blood to expect her to tell before the whole school that she had been called “carrots.” Rowan it was who spoke up stoutly.

“It was my fault Mr. Edwards. I teased her.”

Mr. Edwards paid no heed to Rowan.

“I am sorry to see a pupil of mine displaying such a temper and such a vindictive spirit,” he said in a solemn tone, as if the mere fact of being a pupil of his ought to root out all evil passions from the hearts of small imperfect mortals. “Clara, go and stand on the platform in front of the blackboard for the rest of the afternoon.”

Clara would have infinitely preferred a whipping to this punishment under which her sensitive spirit quivered as from a whiplash. With a white, set face she obeyed. Mr. Edwards took a chalk crayon and wrote on the blackboard above her head.

“Ann Shirley has a very bad temper. Ann Shirley must learn to control her temper,” and then read it out loud so that even the primer class, who couldn’t read writing, should understand it.

Clara stood there the rest of the afternoon with that legend above her. She did not cry or hang her head. Anger was still too hot in her heart for that and it sustained her amid all her agony of humiliation. With resentful eyes and passion-red cheeks she confronted alike Sophia’s sympathetic gaze and Jack Russell’s indignant nods and Hannah Ford’s malicious smiles. As for Rowan Blake, she would not even look at him. She would never look at him again! She would never speak to him!!

When school was dismissed Clara marched out with her red head held high. Rowan Blake tried to intercept her at the porch door.

“I’m awfully sorry I made fun of your hair, Clara,” he whispered contritely. “Honest I am. Don’t be mad for keeps, now.”

Clara swept by disdainfully, without look or sign of hearing. “Oh how could you, Clara?” breathed Sophia as they went down the road half reproachfully, half admiringly. Sophia felt that she could never have resisted Rowan’s plea.

“I shall never forgive Rowan Blake,” said Clara firmly. “And Mr. Edwards spelled my name without an e, too. The iron has entered into my soul, Sophia.”

Sophia hadn’t the least idea what Clara meant but she understood it was something terrible.

“You mustn’t mind Rowan making fun of your hair,” she said soothingly. “Why, he makes fun of all the girls. He laughs at mine because it’s so black. He’s called me a crow a dozen times; and I never heard him apologize for anything before, either.”

“There’s a great deal of difference between being called a crow and being called carrots,” said Clara with dignity. “Rowan Blake has hurt my feelings excruciatingly, Sophia.”

It is possible the matter might have blown over without more excruciation if nothing else had happened. But when things begin to happen they are apt to keep on.

Avonlea scholars often spent noon hour picking gum in Mr. Carter’s spruce grove over the hill and across his big pasture field. From there they could keep an eye on Eben Wright’s house, where the master boarded. When they saw Mr. Edwards emerging therefrom they ran for the schoolhouse; but the distance being about three times longer than Mr. Wright’s lane they were very apt to arrive there, breathless and gasping, some three minutes too late.

On the following day Mr. Edwards was seized with one of his spasmodic fits of reform and announced before going home to dinner, that he should expect to find all the scholars in their seats when he returned. Anyone who came in late would be punished.

All the boys and some of the girls went to Mr. Carter’s spruce grove as usual, fully intending to stay only long enough to “pick a chew.” But spruce groves are seductive and yellow nuts of gum beguiling; they picked and loitered and strayed; and as usual the first thing that recalled them to a sense of the flight of time was Simon Cook shouting from the top of a patriarchal old spruce “Master’s coming.”

The girls who were on the ground, started first and managed to reach the schoolhouse in time but without a second to spare. The boys, who had to wriggle hastily down from the trees, were later; and Clara, who had not been picking gum at all but was wandering happily in the far end of the grove, waist deep among the bracken, singing softly to herself, with a wreath of rice lilies on her hair as if she were some wild divinity of the shadowy places, was latest of all. Clara could run like a deer, however; run she did with the impish result that she overtook the boys at the door and was swept into the schoolhouse among them just as Mr. Edwards was in the act of hanging up his hat.

Mr. Edwards’s brief reforming energy was over; he didn’t want the bother of punishing a dozen pupils; but it was necessary to do something to save his word, so he looked about for a scapegoat and found it in Clara, who had dropped into her seat, gasping for breath, with a forgotten lily wreath hanging askew over one ear and giving her a particularly rakish and disheveled appearance.

“Clara Fisher, since you seem to be so fond of the boys’ company we shall indulge your taste for it this afternoon,” he said sarcastically. “Take those flowers out of your hair and sit with Rowan Blake.”

The other boys snickered. Sophia, turning pale with pity, plucked the wreath from Clara’s hair and squeezed her hand. Clara stared at the master as if turned to stone.

“Did you hear what I said, Clara?” queried Mr. Edwards sternly.

“Yes, sir,” said Clara slowly “but I didn’t suppose you really meant it.”

“I assure you I did”—still with the sarcastic inflection which all the children, and Clara especially, hated. It flicked on the raw. “Obey me at once.”

For a moment Clara looked as if she meant to disobey. Then, realizing that there was no help for it, she rose haughtily, stepped across the aisle, sat down beside Rowan Blake, and buried her face in her arms on the desk. Coral Hayes, who got a glimpse of it as it went down, told the others going home from school that she’d “acksually never seen anything like it—it was so white, with awful little red spots in it.”

To Clara, this was as the end of all things. It was bad enough to be singled out for punishment from among a dozen equally guilty ones; it was worse still to be sent to sit with a boy, but that that boy should be Rowan Blake was heaping insult on injury to a degree utterly unbearable. Clara felt that she could not bear it and it would be of no use to try. Her whole being seethed with shame and anger and humiliation.

At first the other scholars looked and whispered and giggled and nudged. But as Clara never lifted her head and as Rowan worked fractions as if his whole soul was absorbed in them and them only, they soon returned to their own tasks and Clara was forgotten. When Mr. Edwards called the history class out Clara should have gone, but Clara did not move, and Mr. Edwards, who had been writing some verses “To Felicia” before he called the class, was thinking about an obstinate rhyme still and never missed her. Once, when nobody was looking, Rowan took from his desk a little pink candy heart with a gold motto on it, “You are sweet,” and slipped it under the curve of Clara’s arm. Whereupon Clara arose, took the pink heart gingerly between the tips of her fingers, dropped it on the floor, ground it to powder beneath her heel, and resumed her position without deigning to bestow a glance on Rowan.

When school went out Clara marched to her desk, ostentatiously took out everything therein, books and writing tablet, pen and ink, testament and arithmetic, and piled them neatly on her cracked slate.

“What are you taking all those things home for, Clara?” Sophia wanted to know, as soon as they were out on the road. She had not dared to ask the question before.

“I am not coming back to school any more,” said Clara. Sophia gasped and stared at Clara to see if she meant it.

“Will Edna let you stay home?” she asked.

“She’ll have to,” said Clara. “I’ll never go to school to that man again.”

“Oh, Clara!” Sophia looked as if she were ready to cry. “I do think you’re mean. What shall I do? Mr. Edwards will make me sit with that horrid Heather Ford—I know he will because she is sitting alone. Do come back, Clara.”

“I’d do almost anything in the world for you, Sophia,” said Clara sadly. “I’d let myself be torn limb from limb if it would do you any good. But I can’t do this, so please don’t ask it. You harrow up my very soul.”

“Just think of all the fun you will miss,” mourned Sophia. “We are going to build the loveliest new house down by the brook; and we’ll be playing ball next week and you’ve never played ball, Clara. It’s tremendously exciting. And we’re going to learn a new song—Martha Chapman is practicing it up now; and Alice Andrews is going to bring a new Pansy book next week and we’re all going to read it out loud, chapter about, down by the brook. And you know you are so fond of reading out loud, Clara.”

Nothing moved Clara in the least. Her mind was made up. She would not go to school to Mr. Edwards again; she told Edna so when she got home.

“Nonsense,” said Edna.

“It isn’t nonsense at all,” said Clara, gazing at Edna with solemn, reproachful eyes. “Don’t you understand, Edna? I’ve been insulted.”

“Insulted fiddlesticks! You’ll go to school tomorrow as usual.”

“Oh, no.” Clara shook her head gently. “I’m not going back, Edna. I’ll learn my lessons at home and I’ll be as good as I can be and hold my tongue all the time if it’s possible at all. But I will not go back to school, I assure you.”

Edna saw something remarkably like unyielding stubbornness looking out of Clara’s small face. She understood that she would have trouble in overcoming it; but she re-solved wisely to say nothing more just then. “I’ll run down and see Beatrice about it this evening,” she thought. “There’s no use reasoning with Clara now. She’s too worked up and I’ve an idea she can be awful stubborn if she takes the notion. Far as I can make out from her story, Mr. Edwards has been carrying matters with a rather high hand. But it would never do to say so to her. I’ll just talk it over with Beatrice. She’s sent ten children to school and she ought to know something about it. She’ll have heard the whole story, too, by this time.”

Edna found Mrs. Harper knitting quilts as industriously and cheerfully as usual.

“I suppose you know what I’ve come about,” she said, a little shamefacedly.

Mrs. Beatrice nodded.

“About Clara’s fuss in school, I reckon,” she said. “Emma Conner was in on her way home from school and told me about it.”

“I don’t know what to do with her,” said Edna. “She declares she won’t go back to school. I never saw a child so worked up. I’ve been expecting trouble ever since she started to school. I knew things were going too smooth to last. She’s so high strung. What would you advise, Beatrice?”

“Well, since you’ve asked my advice, Edna,” said Mrs. Harper amiably—Mrs. Harper dearly loved to be asked for advice—“I’d just humor her a little at first, that’s what I’d do. It’s my belief that Mr. Edwards was in the wrong. Of course, it doesn’t do to say so to the children, you know. And of course he did right to punish her yesterday for giving way to temper. But today it was different. The others who were late should have been punished as well as Clara, that’s what. And I don’t believe in making the girls sit with the boys for punishment. It isn’t modest. Emma Conner was real indignant. She took Clara’s part right through and said all the scholars did too. Clara seems real popular among them, somehow. I never thought she’d take with them so well.”

“Then you really think I’d better let her stay home,” said Edna in amazement.

“Yes. That is I wouldn’t say school to her again until she said it herself. Depend upon it, Edna, she’ll cool off in a week or so and be ready enough to go back of her own accord, that’s what, while, if you were to make her go back right off, dear knows what freak or tantrum she’d take next and make more trouble than ever. The less fuss made the better, in my opinion. She won’t miss much by not going to school, as far as that goes. Mr. Edwards isn’t any good at all as a teacher. The order he keeps is scandalous, that’s what, and he neglects the young fry and puts all his time on those big scholars he’s getting ready for Queen’s. He’d never have got the school for another year if his uncle hadn’t been a trustee—the trustee, for he just leads the other two around by the nose, that’s what. I declare, I don’t know what education in this Island is coming to.”

Mrs. Beatrice shook her head, as much as to say if she were only at the head of the educational system of the Province things would be much better managed.

Edna took Mrs. Beatrice’s advice and not another word was said to Clara about going back to school. She learned her lessons at home, did her chores, and played with Sophia in the chilly purple autumn twilights; but when she met Rowan Blake on the road or encountered him in Sunday-school she passed him by with an icy contempt that was no whit thawed by his evident desire to appease her. Even Sophia’s efforts as a peacemaker were of no avail. Clara had evidently made up her mind to hate Rowan Blake to the end of life.

As much as she hated Rowan, however, did she love Sophia, with all the love of her passionate little heart, equally intense in its likes and dislikes. One evening Edna, coming in from the orchard with a basket of apples, found Clara sitting along by the east window in the twilight, crying bitterly.

“Whatever’s the matter now, Clara?” she asked.

“It’s about Sophia,” sobbed Clara luxuriously. “I love Sophia so, Edna. I cannot ever live without her. But I know very well when we grow up that Sophia will get married and go away and leave me. And oh, what shall I do? I hate her husband—I just hate him furiously. I’ve been imagining it all out—the wedding and everything—Sophia dressed in snowy garments, with a veil, and looking as beautiful and regal as a queen; and me the bridesmaid, with a lovely dress too, and puffed sleeves, but with a breaking heart hid beneath my smiling face. And then bidding Sophia goodbye-e-e—” Here Clara broke down entirely and wept with increasing bitterness.

Edna turned quickly away to hide her twitching face; but it was no use; she collapsed on the nearest chair and burst into such a hearty and unusual peal of laughter that Donald, crossing the yard outside, halted in amazement. When had he heard Edna laugh like that before?

“Well, Clara Fisher,” said Edna as soon as she could speak, “if you must borrow trouble, for pity’s sake borrow it handier home. I should think you had an imagination, sure enough.”

CHAPTER XVI.
Sophia Is Invited to Tea with Tragic Results
OCTOBER was a beautiful month at Green Gables, when the birches in the hollow turned as golden as sunshine and the maples behind the orchard were royal crimson and the wild cherry-trees along the lane put on the loveliest shades of dark red and bronzy green, while the fields sunned themselves in aftermaths.

Clara reveled in the world of color about her.

“Oh, Edna,” she exclaimed one Saturday morning, coming dancing in with her arms full of gorgeous boughs, “I’m so glad I live in a world where there are Octobers. It would be terrible if we just skipped from September to November, wouldn’t it? Look at these maple branches. Don’t they give you a thrill—several thrills? I’m going to decorate my room with them.”

“Messy things,” said Edna, whose aesthetic sense was not noticeably developed. “You clutter up your room entirely too much with out-of-doors stuff, Clara. Bedrooms were made to sleep in.”

“Oh, and dream in too, Edna. And you know one can dream so much better in a room where there are pretty things. I’m going to put these boughs in the old blue jug and set them on my table.”

“Mind you don’t drop leaves all over the stairs then. I’m going on a meeting of the Aid Society at Carmody this afternoon, Clara, and I won’t likely be home before dark. You’ll have to get Donald and Max their supper, so mind you don’t forget to put the tea to draw until you sit down at the table as you did last time.”

“It was dreadful of me to forget,” said Clara apologetically, “but that was the afternoon I was trying to think of a name for Violet Vale and it crowded other things out. Donald was so good. He never scolded a bit. He put the tea down himself and said we could wait awhile as well as not. And I told him a lovely fairy story while we were waiting, so he didn’t find the time long at all. It was a beautiful fairy story, Edna. I forgot the end of it, so I made up an end for it myself and Donald said he couldn’t tell where the join came in.”

“Donald would think it all right, Clara, if you took a notion to get up and have dinner in the middle of the night. But you keep your wits about you this time. And—I don’t really know if I’m doing right—it may make you more addlepated than ever—but you can ask Sophia to come over and spend the afternoon with you and have tea here.”

“Oh, Edna!” Clara clasped her hands. “How perfectly lovely! You are able to imagine things after all or else you’d never have understood how I’ve longed for that very thing. It will seem so nice and grown-uppish. No fear of my forgetting to put the tea to draw when I have company. Oh, Edna, can I use the rosebud spray tea set?”

“No, indeed! The rosebud tea set! Well, what next? You know I never use that except for the minister or the Aids. You’ll put down the old brown tea set. But you can open the little yellow crock of cherry preserves. It’s time it was being used anyhow—I believe it’s beginning to work. And you can cut some fruit cake and have some of the cookies and snaps.”

“I can just imagine myself sitting down at the head of the table and pouring out the tea,” said Clara, shutting her eyes ecstatically. “And asking Sophia if she takes sugar! I know she doesn’t but of course I’ll ask her just as if I didn’t know. And then pressing her to take another piece of fruit cake and another helping of preserves. Oh, Edna, it’s a wonderful sensation just to think of it. Can I take her into the spare room to lay off her hat when she comes? And then into the parlor to sit?”

“No. The sitting room will do for you and your company. But there’s a bottle half full of raspberry cordial that was left over from the church social the other night. It’s on the second shelf of the sitting-room closet and you and Sophia can have it if you like, and a cooky to eat with it along in the afternoon, for I daresay Donald ‘ll be late coming in to tea since he’s hauling potatoes to the vessel.”

Clara flew down to the hollow, past the Dryad’s Bubble and up the spruce path to Orchard Slope, to ask Sophia to tea. As a result just after Edna had driven off to Carmody, Sophia came over, dressed in her second-best dress and looking exactly as it is proper to look when asked out to tea. At other times she was wont to run into the kitchen without knocking; but now she knocked primly at the front door. And when Clara, dressed in her second best, as primly opened it, both little girls shook hands as gravely as if they had never met before. This unnatural solemnity lasted until after Sophia had been taken to the east gable to lay off her hat and then had sat for ten minutes in the sitting room, toes in position.

“How is your mother?” inquired Clara politely, just as if she had not seen Mrs. Greene picking apples that morning in excellent health and spirits.

“She is very well, thank you. I suppose Mr. Forsythe is hauling potatoes to the lily sands this afternoon, is he?” said Sophia, who had ridden down to Mr. Marvin Chapman’s that morning in Donald’s cart.

“Yes. Our potato crop is very good this year. I hope your father’s crop is good too.”

“It is fairly good, thank you. Have you picked many of your apples yet?”

“Oh, ever so many,” said Clara forgetting to be dignified and jumping up quickly. “Let’s go out to the orchard and get some of the Red Sweetings, Sophia. Edna says we can have all that are left on the tree. Edna is a very generous woman. She said we could have fruit cake and cherry preserves for tea. But it isn’t good manners to tell your company what you are going to give them to eat, so I won’t tell you what she said we could have to drink. Only it begins with an R and a C and it’s bright red color. I love bright red drinks, don’t you? They taste twice as good as any other color.”

The orchard, with its great sweeping boughs that bent to the ground with fruit, proved so delightful that the little girls spent most of the afternoon in it, sitting in a grassy corner where the frost had spared the green and the mellow autumn sunshine lingered warmly, eating apples and talking as hard as they could. Sophia had much to tell Clara of what went on in school. She had to sit with Heather Ford and she hated it; Gertie squeaked her pencil all the time and it just made her—Sophia’s—blood run cold; Coral Hayes had charmed all her warts away, true’s you live, with a magic pebble that old Grace Nigel from the Creek gave her. You had to rub the warts with the pebble and then throw it away over your left shoulder at the time of the new moon and the warts would all go. Jack Russell’s name was written up with Beau White’s on the porch wall and Beau White was awful mad about it; Frank Conner had “sassed” Mr. Edwards in class and Mr. Edwards whipped him and Sam’s father came down to the school and dared Mr. Edwards to lay a hand on one of his children again; and Linda Chapman had a new red hood and a blue crossover with tassels on it and the airs she put on about it were perfectly sickening; and Nina Grant didn’t speak to Jenny McGee because Jenny McGee’s grown-up sister had cut out Nina Grant’s grown-up sister with her beau; and everybody missed Clara so and wished she’s come to school again; and Rowan Blake—

But Clara didn’t want to hear about Rowan Blake. She jumped up hurriedly and said suppose they go in and have some raspberry cordial.

Clara looked on the second shelf of the room pantry but there was no bottle of raspberry cordial there. Search revealed it away back on the top shelf. Clara put it on a tray and set it on the table with a tumbler.

“Now, please help yourself, Sophia,” she said politely. “I don’t believe I’ll have any just now. I don’t feel as if I wanted any after all those apples.”

Sophia poured herself out a tumblerful, looked at its bright-red hue admiringly, and then sipped it daintily.

“That’s awfully nice raspberry cordial, Clara,” she said. “I didn’t know raspberry cordial was so nice.”

“I’m real glad you like it. Take as much as you want. I’m going to run out and stir the fire up. There are so many responsibilities on a person’s mind when they’re keeping house, isn’t there?”

When Clara came back from the kitchen Sophia was drinking her second glassful of cordial; and, being entreated thereto by Clara, she offered no particular objection to the drinking of a third. The tumblerfuls were generous ones and the raspberry cordial was certainly very nice.

“The nicest I ever drank,” said Sophia. “It’s ever so much nicer than Mrs. Harper’s, although she brags of hers so much. It doesn’t taste a bit like hers.”

“I should think Edna’s raspberry cordial would prob’ly be much nicer than Mrs. Harper’s,” said Clara loyally. “Edna is a famous cook. She is trying to teach me to cook but I assure you, Sophia, it is uphill work. There’s so little scope for imagination in cookery. You just have to go by rules. The last time I made a cake I forgot to put the flour in. I was thinking the loveliest story about you and me, Sophia. I thought you were desperately ill with smallpox and everybody deserted you, but I went boldly to your bedside and nursed you back to life; and then I took the smallpox and died and I was buried under those poplar trees in the graveyard and you planted a rosebush by my grave and watered it with your tears; and you never, never forgot the friend of your youth who sacrificed her life for you. Oh, it was such a pathetic tale, Sophia. The tears just rained down over my cheeks while I mixed the cake. But I forgot the flour and the cake was a dismal failure. Flour is so essential to cakes, you know. Edna was very cross and I don’t wonder. I’m a great trial to her. She was terribly mortified about the pudding sauce last week. We had a plum pudding for dinner on Tuesday and there was half the pudding and a pitcherful of sauce left over. Edna said there was enough for another dinner and told me to set it on the pantry shelf and cover it. I meant to cover it just as much as could be, Sophia, but when I carried it in I was imagining I was
